stem: The nurse is caring for a patient receiving mechanical ventilation. Which of the following nursing interventions are MOST important to prevent ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)? Select all that apply.

itemContext.sbar: Situation: Robert Miller, a 68-year-old male, is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to acute respiratory failure secondary to pneumonia. Background: Mr. Miller was admitted three days ago with a productive cough, fever, and shortness of breath. He has a history of COPD and hypertension. Assessment: At 07:00, his vital signs are: HR 110, BP 150/90, RR 16 (ventilator settings: FiO2 40%, PEEP 5 cm H2O, Tidal Volume 500 mL), SpO2 92%. He is on continuous sedation with propofol. Lung sounds reveal coarse crackles bilaterally. ETCO2 is 38 mmHg. Current medications include vancomycin and azithromycin. Recommendation: Please assess for signs of VAP and continue vigilant respiratory care. At 08:00, note increased secretions and decreased oxygen saturation to 89%. Consider suctioning and potential changes in ventilator settings. Assess sedation level per RASS scale.

rationale.correct: Elevating the head of the bed to 30-45 degrees reduces the risk of aspiration. Performing regular oral care with chlorhexidine decreases the bacterial load in the mouth, reducing the risk of VAP. Suctioning secretions when needed prevents pooling of secretions and bacterial colonization in the lower airways. Ensuring proper hand hygiene before and after patient contact is crucial to prevent the spread of infection. Assessing endotracheal tube cuff pressure regularly (aiming for 20-30 cm H2O) prevents leakage of secretions into the lower airway.
rationale.incorrect: Routine antibiotic prophylaxis is not recommended due to the risk of antibiotic resistance. While repositioning is important for preventing pressure ulcers, it does not directly address VAP prevention. Increasing the FiO2 to 100% is not a preventative measure for VAP and can lead to oxygen toxicity. Instilling normal saline before suctioning is no longer recommended as it can dislodge bacteria deeper into the lungs.
clinicalPearls: VAP is a significant complication of mechanical ventilation, increasing morbidity and mortality.
Adherence to VAP prevention bundles is crucial for reducing the incidence of VAP.
Continuous aspiration of subglottic secretions (CASS) is another important intervention to prevent VAP in high-risk patients.

questionTrap.trap: Several options seem like standard nursing care, but the question focuses on VAP prevention specifically.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the pathophysiology of VAP and which interventions directly address the mechanisms leading to its development (e.g., aspiration, bacterial colonization).

mnemonic.title: VAP BUNDLE
mnemonic.expansion: V: Ventilator settings optimization; A: Aseptic technique; P: Positioning (HOB elevation); B: Breathing exercises and weaning assessment; U: Understanding and adherence to protocols; N: Nutrition; D: Daily sedation vacation; L: Lung hygiene (oral care, suctioning); E: Early mobility
